articles.contents:
Jessica Schaaf
          
          
          Contact
          Research
          Science Communication
          ☰
          
          
      
        
          
            Jessica Schaaf
          
          
            
              
              I’m Jessica Schaaf, a postdoctoral researcher
              interested in how cognitive abilities develop with age and
              individual differences therein. To understand this, I
              mostly use experiments in combination with Bayesian
              computational modeling. Aside from research, I love to do
              some fun creative science communication.
              When my schedule allows it, I’m very happy to start new
              projects, participate in science communication activities,
              and consult on data analyses, so please feel free to reach
              out.

articles.title: Welcome!
articles.contents:
Have you ever wondered why you can easily remember where you parked your car one day, but spend minutes on finding it another day? Or why some people are much more affected by a poor night’s sleep than for others? Such questions keep bothering me and that’s why I investigate them.
I mostly do so through experiments and mathematical modeling. In this way, I can get to the bottom of the processes underlying cognitive capacities like memory, learning, and decision-making.

articles.title: Science Communication
articles.contents:
Contents
Teaching packages and educational videos
Popular writing (articles and blogs)
Participation in the Hoe?Zo! Show (2020/2021)


I find it important and rewarding to communicate my findings in an understandable manner. As such, I try to come up with fun ways to show the public what I’m working on. Think of infographics, blogs, theater shows, exhibitions, etc.

Teaching packages and educational videos
Together with Sophie Hofman and Feline van Aagten from the Lifespan Cognitive Dynamics lab, I developed teaching packages for elementary-school children. These packages include lectures and videos on being a scientist and on the brain, specifically on senses and memory.
Being a scientist


The brain: Senses


The brain: Memory


Popular writing (articles and blogs)
When I come across cool papers or news items about (the development of) cognitive performance and/or cognitive fluctuations, I like to write about it. I recently wrote a blog on the importance of science communication and on cognitive fluctuations in the context of the American presidential elections.
I also wrote an article on giftedness in adults for the trade journal De Psycholoog with clinical psychologist Pleun van Vliet. An example of the good things that happen when scientist meets clinician!
Participation in the Hoe?Zo! Show (2020/2021)
As a PhD student, I was lucky to participate in the award winning Hoe?Zo! Show, a science theater show for 9- to 10-year-olds developed by Barbara Braams and Lennart de Groot, and presented by Boy Vissers. The goal of the show was to get children excited about science while at the same time teaching the PhD students how to communicate science in an understandable manner. Over 500 children could ask their burning questions which I, together with fellow PhDs from a variety of fields, answered on the spot in a creative and age-appropriate manner. Our season was featured in Trouw and many local news outlets.

articles.title: Work
articles.contents:
Contents
Ongoing projects
Time series
Reinforcement learning

Papers
Most recent papers and preprints
Reinforcement Learning
Decision Making



Most of my work concerns (computational) modeling of cognitive processes, including learning and decision making. I’m currently employed at the Lifespan Cognitive Dynamics lab at the Donders Institute in Nijmegen. Below you can find ongoing projects (feel free to reach out for potential collaborations!), and links and short author summaries of my papers; sometimes accompanied by slides and/or visual summaries of the papers.


You can find my dissertation on the development of reinforcement learning strategies here.
Ongoing projects
Time series
Bidirectional relationships between depressive mood and cognition. In collaboration with Ema Jovanovic and Rogier Kievit (Donders/Radboudumc).
The role of sleep quality in cognitive variability: A dynamic structural equation modeling approach. In collaboration with Afon Khari and Rogier Kievit (Donders/Radboudumc).
Reinforcement learning
Feedback matters: Children’s feedback sensitivity in a large online learning platform. In collaboration with Michael Aristodemou, Rogier Kievit, and Prowise Learn (Donders/Radboudumc, UvA).
Inter- and intra-individual differences in exploratory behavior. In collaboration with Rogier Kievit and the CODEC team (Donders/Radboudumc).
Understanding, improving, and computational modeling of adolescents’ climate-friendly choice. In collaboration with Wouter van den Bos, Cameron Brick, Hilde Huizenga, Lucas Molleman, and Peter Verkoeijen (UvA, EUR, Avans).
Working memory use in reinforcement learning in older adults. In collaboration with Leendert van Maanen and Irene van de Vijver (UU).
Papers
Most recent papers and preprints
Schaaf, J. V., Miletic, S., Van Duijvenvoorde, A. C. K., & Huizenga, H. M. (2025). Interpretation of individual differences in compuational neuroscience using a latent input approach. Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience, 101512.
Schaaf, J. V., Sorensen, O., McCormick, E. M., Aristodemou, A., & Kievit, R. A. (2024). Uncovering asymmetric temporal dynamics using threshold dynamics parameters. PsyArXiV.
Schaaf, J. V., Dekkers, L. M. S., Kevenaar, S. T., Seijdel, N., Weeda, W. D., Jansen, B. R. J., Visser, I., & Huizenga, H. M. (2024). First things first? Decision strategies in a consecutive contexts. PsyArXiV.
Reinforcement Learning
Schaaf, J. V., Johansson, A., Visser, I., & Huizenga, H. M. (2024). What’s in a name: The role of verbalization in reinforcement learning. Psychonomic Bulletin & Review.
Schaaf, J. V., Weidinger, L., Molleman, L., & Van den Bos, W. (2024). Test-retest reliability of reinforcement learning parameters. Behavior Research Methods, 56, 4582-4599.
Kramer, A.-W., Schaaf, J. V., & Huizenga, H. M. (2023). High-school students’ willingness to invest effort in valenced feedback-learning tasks. Learning and Individual Differences, 108, 102375.
Schaaf, J. V., Xu, B., Jepma, M., Visser, I., & Huizenga, H. M. (2022). (Mal)Adaptive learning after switches between object-based and rule-based environments. Computational Brain & Behavior, 5, 157-167.
Jepma, M., Schaaf, J. V., Visser, I., & Huizenga, H. M. (2022). Impaired learning to dissociate advantageous and disadvantageous risky choices in adolescents. Scientific Reports, 12(1), 6490.
Jepma, M., Schaaf, J. V., Visser, I., & Huizenga, H. M. (2022). Effects of advice on experience-based learning in adolescents and adults. Journal of Experimental Child Psychology, 211, 105230.
Jepma, M., Schaaf, J. V., Visser, I., & Huizenga, H. M. (2020). Uncertainty-driven regulation of learning and exploration in adolescents: A computational account.
PLoS Computational Biology, 16(9), e1008276.
Schaaf, J. V., Jepma, M., Visser, I., & Huizenga, H. M. (2019). A hierarchical Bayesian approach to assess learning and guessing strategies in reinforcement learning. Journal of Mathematical Psychology, 93, 102276.
Decision Making
Zadelaar, J. N., Agelink van Rentergem, J. A., Schaaf, J. V., Dekkers, T. J., De Vent, N., Dekkers, L. M. S., Olthof, M. C., Jansen, B. R. J., & Huizenga, H. M. (2021). Development of decision making based on internal and external information: A hierarchical Bayesian approach. Judgment and Decision Making, 16(6), 1413-1438.
